abstracts.cdata!:
Overall project outcome is satisfactory,
            while project sustainability is rated as likely. Despite
            there being frequent staff turnover and the country's
            generally poor security situation, the overall performance
            of the World Bank is rated as satisfactory. Overall Borrower
            performance is rated satisfactory: the poor performance of
            the line ministries was more than compensated by the good
            perfomance of the implementation agency and by the support
            provided to FAS (the Social Action Fund). Some of the
            lessons learned from the project comprise the following: The
            experiments supported by the project preparation facility
            helped shape many strategic choices for FAS; by the same
            token, components which are not properly prepred should be
            avoided, in this case in the complex field of micro-credit.
            Social funds with clear and transparent policies and
            methodologies can work well even in a difficult environment
            such as Angola. It is important to ensure the early
            establishment of a comprehensive program of community
            training in the full cycle of sub-project identification,
            preparation, contracting, operation, and maintenance, in
            order to improve sustainability. Organizational arrangements
            that cause friction and resentment should be avoided, since
            they harm the delivery of the project: too much harmony and
            too high salaries for the Office for Monitoring LIving
            Conditions of the Population (GMCVP) were in part the reason
            why the project component could not relate and integrated
            well with INE.

            ANALYSIS PRG,TF036182-ANGOLA - SOCIAL ACTION FUND,TF020404-SOCIAL ACTION PROGRAM,TF024626-CTF FOR POVERTY ASSESSMENTS: AFRICA,TF021586-SOCIAL ACTION FUND,TF033178-ANGOLA - HEALTH
18153888.majtheme: Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Action Project aims to assist
            Angola in its transition from war to peace, targeting in
            particular the people impoverished by the military and
            economic crises. The objectives of the project are to: 1)
            improve access to basic services through the provision or
            rehabilitation of community infrastructure; 2) improve the
            capacity of communities and nongovernmental organizations
            (NGOs) to plan, appraise, manage and maintain investment
            activities, through experience gained in the project; 3)
            generate additional income and employment in rural and urban
            areas through revenue-generating sub-projects; 4) enhance
            the capacity of Angolan institutions to collect and analyze
            poverty-related data; and 5) provide a better understanding
            of the main causes of poverty in order to help formulate
            effective poverty alleviation strategies and generate
            adequate policies for socioeconomic development. The project
            consists of the following two components: 1) a social action
            fund component which will finance sub-projects identified,
            prepared and implemented by local communities; and 2) a
            poverty monitoring component which will finance
            policy-relevant research on poverty and social issues, and
            systematic poverty monitoring through household surveys.
